title: Laser Diffraction by a Grating: Beam Locations on a Screen
description: Calculate the locations of first, second, and third-order diffraction beams on a screen when a laser interacts with a diffraction grating.
insight: The angles of diffracted beams can be calculated using the grating equation, and their positions on a screen can be determined using trigonometric relationships.
question_text: A HeNe laser beam (λ = 633 nm) travels along the z-axis and is incident on a grating of spatial frequency 742 cy/mm. Find the locations of the first, second, and third-order beams on a screen 1 m away when the grating is perpendicular to the z-axis.
hint: Use the grating equation: $$\sin(\theta_{out}) = m \lambda f$$, where $$f$$ is the spatial frequency of the grating. Then calculate the position on the screen using $$x = z \cdot \tan(\theta_{out})$$.

solution.final_answer: x₁ = 532 mm, x₂ = 2730 mm, x₃ = Evanescent
steps: Use the grating equation: $$\sin(\theta_{out}) = m \lambda f$$.
Substitute the given values: $$\lambda = 633 \times 10^{-9} \text{ m}$$, $$f = 742 \text{ cycles/mm} = 742 \times 10^3 \text{ cycles/m}$$.
For each order (m=1, m=2, m=3), calculate $$\theta_{out}$$ using $$\arcsin(m \lambda f)$$.
Use $$x = z \cdot \tan(\theta_{out})$$ to calculate the position on the screen (z=1 m).
Evaluate for m=3: $$\theta_{out}$$ exceeds the critical angle, resulting in evanescent behavior.
Conclusion: The first-order beam is at 532 mm, the second-order beam is at 2730 mm, and the third-order beam is evanescent.
